sections.title: The Genealogy from Adam to Abraham

verses.text: Adam, Seth, Enosh.
verses.comment: The genealogy opens with Adam, emphasizing the beginning of humanity. This establishes a foundation for the continuity of divine election, which is fulfilled in Christ. Compare with Genesis 5:1-3 and Luke 3:38.
verses.sectionHeader: The Genealogy from Adam to Abraham

verses.text: Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared.
verses.comment: Genealogy continues tracing the line towards Noah—each name highlights the passing down of the biblical promises.

verses.text: Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech.
verses.comment: Enoch is notable for 'walking with God' and being taken—see Hebrews 11:5 for spiritual implications of faithful living and divine reward.

verses.text: Noah; Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.comment: Noah’s sons mark key divisions of nations and the future direction of salvation history. Shem's descendants link to Abraham and ultimately the Messiah.

verses.text: The sons of Japheth: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
verses.comment: Japheth and his sons represent many Gentile nations, paving the way for future inclusion of all peoples—see Acts 10:34-35.

verses.text: The sons of Gomer: Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah.
verses.comment: These names define further branches of the peoples descended from Japheth. They are obscure but point to the spread of humanity after the flood.

verses.text: The sons of Javan: Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim.
verses.comment: These peoples are typically linked to regions around the Mediterranean, foreshadowing the widespread reach of future salvation.

verses.text: The sons of Ham: Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
verses.comment: Ham’s lineage includes major ancient civilizations (Cush—Ethiopia, Mizraim—Egypt, Canaan). These would play significant roles in biblical history.

verses.text: The sons of Cush: Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. The sons of Raama: Sheba and Dedan.
verses.comment: The genealogies continue, and figures like Sheba and Dedan become notable in later prophecies (see Ezekiel 38:13).

verses.text: Cush fathered Nimrod. He was the first on earth to be a mighty man.
verses.comment: Nimrod, legendary for ‘being mighty’, is traditionally associated with the founding of Babylon. Typologically, his kingdom prefigures the necessity of God's intervention.

verses.text: Mizraim fathered the Ludim, the Anamim, the Lehabim, the Naphtuhim,
verses.comment: These nations are linked to Egypt, highlighting the diversity and spread of Ham’s descendants.

verses.text: the Pathrusim, the Casluhim, from whom the Philistines came, and the Caphtorim.
verses.comment: The genealogies explain the origins of the Philistines, later opponents of Israel and key part of the biblical historical drama.

verses.text: Canaan fathered Sidon, his firstborn, and Heth,
verses.comment: Sidon and Heth are ancestors to major nations—Sidon in Phoenicia, and Heth to the Hittites, which are prominent in biblical history.

verses.text: and the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
verses.comment: These are among the Canaanite peoples who would later inhabit the land promised to Israel.

verses.text: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
verses.comment: More descendants of Canaan, all groups with whom Israel would interact in its history.

verses.text: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites.
verses.comment: Marks the completion of the descendants of Canaan, emphasizing the scope and diversity of the nations.

verses.text: The descendants of Shem: Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, Aram, Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech.
verses.comment: This verse lists Shem’s sons, who became progenitors of ancient Near Eastern peoples; their names represent the nations descending from Shem, including Assyria, Elam, and Aram (see Genesis 10:22-23).

verses.text: Arpachshad became the father of Shelah; and Shelah became the father of Eber.
verses.comment: The genealogy narrows to Arpachshad, Shelah, and Eber, highlighting the lineage through which the Hebrew people emerge, as Eber is considered the ancestor of the 'Hebrews' (cf. Genesis 10:24; 11:14-16).

verses.text: To Eber were born two sons: the name of the one was Peleg, for in his days the earth was divided, and his brother’s name was Joktan.
verses.comment: Peleg’s name recalls the 'division' of languages at Babel—a pivotal event in the story of humanity’s dispersion and eventual restoration.

verses.text: Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
verses.comment: Names surrounding Joktan indicate diverse tribes scattered over Arabia, a sign of humanity's reach and the universality of redemption.

verses.text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
verses.comment: Genealogy repeats, showing the unity of Scripture. These lines reinforce the historicity and continuity of God’s work.

verses.text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
verses.comment: Sheba is important for later prophecies (see Psalm 72:10), spiritually fulfilled in the coming of the Magi (Matthew 2).

verses.text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were the sons of Joktan.
verses.comment: Ophir is noted for riches, linking to wisdom traditions and the glory of Solomon, a type of Christ's kingship.

verses.text: Shem, Arpachshad, Shelah;
verses.comment: This condensed genealogy emphasizes the chosen line from Shem to Shelah, preparing for the introduction of Abraham’s ancestry, underscoring God’s purpose through particular generations.

verses.text: Eber, Peleg, Reu;
verses.comment: Eber’s descendants Peleg and Reu continue the line leading to Abraham, with Peleg notably linked to the division of peoples (Genesis 10:25), situating the genealogical list within the framework of early post-Flood history.

verses.text: Serug, Nahor, Terah;
verses.comment: Serug, Nahor, and Terah are listed as patriarchs bridging the antediluvian world and the Abrahamic covenant, underscoring continuity in salvation history (cf. Genesis 11:20-26).

verses.text: Abram, that is, Abraham.
verses.comment: Abram, renamed Abraham, marks a major transition—the beginning of God’s covenant with a chosen people; the Chronicler highlights him as a foundational figure (Genesis 17:5).

verses.text: The sons of Abraham: Isaac and Ishmael.
verses.comment: Isaac and Ishmael indicate the two main branches of Abraham’s descendants, reflecting the formation of Israel and many surrounding nations (cf. Genesis 21-25).

verses.text: These are their genealogies: the firstborn of Ishmael, Nebaioth; and Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
verses.comment: Ishmael’s sons, starting with Nebaioth and Kedar, illustrate the fulfillment of God’s promise that Ishmael would be a father of twelve princes (Genesis 17:20).

verses.text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema,
verses.comment: This list continues Ishmael’s princes, many of whom became tribal leaders across Arabia, highlighting the broad scope of Abraham’s legacy (Genesis 25:13-15).

verses.text: Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah. These are the sons of Ishmael.
verses.comment: The enumeration of Ishmael's sons completes his genealogy, emphasizing the proliferation of Abraham’s seed beyond Israel, consistent with God's blessing to Hagar (Genesis 25:16).

verses.text: The sons of Keturah, Abraham’s concubine: she bore Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. The sons of Jokshan: Sheba and Dedan.
verses.comment: Keturah’s sons, including Jokshan (whose sons Sheba and Dedan are named), represent additional descendants of Abraham, many of whom are associated with Arabian tribes (Genesis 25:1-4).

verses.text: The sons of Midian: Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were the descendants of Keturah.
verses.comment: Midian’s sons are listed, Midian being a significant group in biblical history (e.g., Moses' sojourn in Midian), showing that Abraham's offspring influenced various peoples and events (Exodus 2:15; Judges 6:1-5).

verses.text: Abraham became the father of Isaac. The sons of Isaac: Esau and Israel.
verses.comment: The genealogy returns to the chosen line through Isaac, differentiating Esau (the ancestor of Edom) and Israel (Jacob), affirming the unique role of Jacob in covenant history (Genesis 25:19-26).

verses.text: The sons of Esau: Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
verses.comment: Esau’s sons are identified, representing tribal leaders of Edom, whose ongoing relationship and rivalry with Israel shaped much of the Old Testament narrative (Genesis 36:10-11).

verses.text: The sons of Eliphaz: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, Kenaz, and by Timna, Amalek.
verses.comment: Amalek is significant as a later enemy of Israel. Many names here become tribal leaders.

verses.text: The sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
verses.comment: The specificity in genealogy demonstrates the thoroughness and reliability of the Bible as historical record.

verses.text: The sons of Seir: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.
verses.comment: Seir’s descendants become the Horite chiefs. These details ground later narratives in the shared land and history.

verses.text: The sons of Lotan: Hori and Hemam; and Lotan’s sister was Timna.
verses.comment: Timna is unusual, included by name, showing the inclusive detail of biblical genealogy which anticipates the spiritual equality of all in God’s plan.

verses.text: The sons of Shobal: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam. The sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah.
verses.comment: Shobal and Zibeon’s descendants are listed as tribal leaders. These records display the fullness of God’s providence, which orders all families for a purpose.

verses.text: The sons of Anah: Dishon. The sons of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Keran.
verses.comment: This genealogy matches Genesis 36:26, showing the close connection between Chronicles and Genesis genealogies. These details underscore God's providential ordering of the nations, a recurrent biblical theme.

verses.text: The sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan. The sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
verses.comment: Uz is notably mentioned as the land where Job dwelled (Job 1:1), connecting this genealogy to later wisdom literature. This hints at the unity of the Scriptures and the broad sweep of salvation history.

verses.text: These are the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the Israelites: Bela the son of Beor, and the name of his city was Dinhabah.
verses.comment: The chronicler highlights the pre-Israelite governance in Edom. This anticipates Israel's later monarchy, seen as part of God’s greater plan for a unified kingdom.

verses.text: Bela died, and Jobab the son of Zerah from Bozrah reigned in his place.
verses.comment: ‘Bozrah’ is later prophetically referenced as a place of judgment (Isaiah 34:6), which alludes to future theological themes of kingship and Messianic expectation.

verses.text: Jobab died, and Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his place.
verses.comment: Teman is noted elsewhere as a region of wisdom (Jeremiah 49:7), reinforcing theological connections between Edom and Israel’s story.

verses.text: Husham died, and Hadad the son of Bedad, who struck down Midian in the field of Moab, reigned in his place. The name of his city was Avith.
verses.comment: The reference to Hadad’s military victory shows God’s sovereignty in national events. These accounts of Edomite kings prefigure the significance of anointed kingship in Israel.

verses.text: Hadad died, and Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his place.
verses.comment: The sequential listing of kings builds a sense of historical continuity, seen later in Israel's own royal line ending ultimately in Christ, the true King (Matthew 1:1).

verses.text: Samlah died, and Shaul of Rehoboth by the River reigned in his place.
verses.comment: ‘Rehoboth by the River’ remains a somewhat mysterious location. The chronicling of foreign kings provides historical context demonstrating God’s providence over even the nations beyond Israel.

verses.text: Shaul died, and Baal-hanan the son of Achbor reigned in his place.
verses.comment: The recurring kingly succession hints at the persistence of authority and structure, which later comes to fullness in God's establishment of the House of David (2 Samuel 7:16).

verses.text: Baal-hanan died, and Hadad reigned in his place. The name of his city was Pai; and his wife’s name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, the daughter of Mezahab.
verses.comment: Mehetabel is unique among these lists as a woman’s name is preserved, underscoring the importance of genealogy for both legal and theological reasons in biblical history.

verses.text: Hadad died. Chiefs of Edom were: Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
verses.comment: With Hadad’s death, the list transitions from individual kings to chiefs, marking a new stage in Edomite society. Leadership structures are a recurring pattern in Scripture, reflecting order instituted by God.

verses.text: Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
verses.comment: Oholibamah is another example of a woman whose name is featured, signifying the comprehensive nature of biblical genealogies and possibly hinting at spiritual allegories found later in prophetic books.

verses.text: Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
verses.comment: Kenaz and Teman represent lineages connected with wisdom and strength (Job 2:11). Such genealogical listings are critical for understanding the structure and continuity of God’s people.

verses.text: Magdiel, and Iram—these are the chiefs of Edom.
verses.comment: The chronicler’s record ends here for the Edomite chiefs, setting the stage for Israel’s distinctive calling among the nations and the eventual fulfillment of God’s promises in Christ (Luke 4:17-21).
